newsitem.title: USA: CSCE cocoa ends higher in lightly traded session.
newsitem.headline: CSCE cocoa ends higher in lightly traded session.

text.p: CSCE cocoa futures ended higher in thin dealings on Tuesday, bolstered by light speculative interest and industry-linked buying, market sources said.

After pulling back for two sessions in a row, traders said the market was due for a technical correction. Prices headed higher at the opening and stayed in positive territory for the remainder of the session.
Traders said a downturn in the U.S. dollar against the British pound also buoyed CSCE cocoa, as arbitrage favored cheaper prices on the dollar-denominated New York market.
"Industry was taking adavantage of the break in prices," said one trader. "And the weaker dollar helped New York a little."
May futures rose $17 a tonne on the day, to $1,445, having traded from $1,451 to $1,430. May gained $11, to $1,471, while the remaining months were up $9 to $12.
Traders said upward momentum picked up after the key May contract broke through near-term chart resistance at $1,440 a tonne and triggered buy-stops.
But scattered scale-up selling by the trade trimmed gains and kept May below its next level of resistance at $1,453, they added.
Technically, traders said a breach of $1,453 basis May contract could lead to a test of $1,460-$1,463. On the downside, near-term support was seen around today's low of $1,430.

Fundamentally, traders said views were mixed. While some dealers said an anticipated global cocoa deficit in 1996/97 and strong consumption should provide support for prices, other dealers said arrival figures out of the Ivory Coast could point to a larger-than-expected harvest from the world's number one producer.

"Consumption has been excellent," said Rich Wistisen, an analysts with Commodity Information in Orem, Utah. "But Ivorian arrivals are already up near one million tonnes and the mid-crop is developing well."

Wistisen said the 1996/97 Ivorian harvest is likely to be close to last season's record yield of 1.2 million tonnes. Many analysts have forecast a 1996/97 Ivory Coast crop of over one million tonnes, but the Ivorian Commodities Minister Guy-Alain Gauze said earlier this month the total harvest was likely to be less than one million tonnes.
The day's volume reached an estimated 5,108 lots, down from Monday's official tally of 7,600 lots.
